pullRequest.body:
The derivative of a convex function is monotone (variations on a theme)

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

Note to reviewers: the bulk of this PR comes from a simple lemma relating slopes of secants to derivatives at their endpoints. In attempt to cover all use cases I ended up proving 24 different variations of this lemma: left/right endpoints, strict/nonstrict, concave/convex, and one-sided deriv/derivWithin/usual deriv. 

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I've added `HasDeriv[Within]At` versions of everything (and gotten rid of the `UniqueDiffWithinAt` statement since it's no longer needed). The resulting code is now about 150 lines longer than before, but hopefully covers every imaginable use case.

:v: loefflerd can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8602277833/job/23571483557)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8602277833/job/23571483854)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8602277833/job/23571484449)

Thanks!

bors d+

Why not do something like this:
```suggestion
lemma uniqueDiffOn_convex_of_nontrivial {S : Set ℝ} (hS : Convex ℝ S) (hS' : S.Nontrivial) :
    UniqueDiffOn ℝ S := by
  refine uniqueDiffOn_convex hS ?_
  rcases hS'.exists_lt with ⟨x, hx, y, hy, hxy⟩
  refine .mono (interior_mono <| hS.ordConnected.out hx hy) ?_
  simp only [interior_Icc,nonempty_Ioo, hxy]
```

Is the `Nontrivial` hypothesis more annoying later?
(The name change is to match the existing `uniqueDiffOn_convex`)

On second thought, maybe it would be more natural to write this as a lemma about `OrdConnected` ? They are equivalent in that context, but that makes it clearer that this is only about the 1D case. What do you think ?

I'm afraid that the `Nontrivial` hypothesis is definitely more annoying later. Currently this is used as
`hfc.1.uniqueDiffWithinAt hy hx hxy.ne'` (inside an argument of a simp lemma). With this suggested reformulation, it would become
````
(uniqueDiffOn_ordConnected_of_nontrivial hfc.1.ordConnected 
      (Set.nontrivial_of_exists_lt ⟨_, hx, _, hy, hxy⟩)) y hy)
````
which is far more annoying.

(Note that I'm deliberately re-using `x` here: it's both the point at which we want the derivative to be unique, and one of the elements of `S` we use to establish nontriviality. This is order to minimise the number of arguments to be supplied at the point of use, and you can't do this if you go via `UniqueDiffOn`.)

I think this is the perfect example where using `Has[F]Deriv[Within]At` would make your life easier. If you split `right_deriv_le_slope` into these two lemmas:
```lean
variable {f' : ℝ}

lemma le_slope_of_hasDerivWithinAt_Ioi (hfc : ConvexOn ℝ S f) (hx : x ∈ S)
    (hy : y ∈ S) (hxy : x < y) (hfd : HasDerivWithinAt f f' (Ioi x) x) :
    f' ≤ slope f x y := by
  apply le_of_tendsto <| (hasDerivWithinAt_iff_tendsto_slope' not_mem_Ioi_self).mp hfd
  simp_rw [eventually_nhdsWithin_iff, slope_def_field]
  filter_upwards [eventually_lt_nhds hxy] with t ht (ht' : x < t)
  refine hfc.secant_mono hx (?_ : t ∈ S) hy ht'.ne' hxy.ne' ht.le
  exact hfc.1.ordConnected.out hx hy ⟨ht'.le, ht.le⟩

lemma right_deriv_le_slope (hfc : ConvexOn ℝ S f) (hx : x ∈ S) (hy : y ∈ S) (hxy : x < y)
    (hfd : DifferentiableWithinAt ℝ f (Ioi x) x) :
    derivWithin f (Ioi x) x ≤ slope f x y :=
  hfc.le_slope_of_hasDerivWithinAt_Ioi hx hy hxy hfd.hasDerivWithinAt
```
Then this simply becomes:
```suggestion
lemma le_slope_of_hasDerivWithinAt (hfc : ConvexOn ℝ S f) (hx : x ∈ S) (hy : y ∈ S) (hxy : x < y)
    (hfd : HasDerivWithinAt f f' S x) :
    f' ≤ slope f x y := by
  have : S ∈ 𝓝[>] x := sorry
  refine hfc.le_slope_of_hasDerivWithinAt_Ioi hx hy hxy (hfd.mono_of_mem this)

lemma derivWithin_le_slope (hfc : ConvexOn ℝ S f) (hx : x ∈ S) (hy : y ∈ S) (hxy : x < y)
    (hfd : DifferentiableWithinAt ℝ f S x) :
    derivWithin f S x ≤ slope f x y :=
  hfc.le_slope_of_hasDerivWithinAt hx hy hxy hfd.hasDerivWithinAt
```
Side note: the sorry in this code can reasonably be its own lemma about `OrdConnected` sets imho.

Obviously you don't necessarily have to have all variations in terms of `HasDerivWithinAt` for it to work, but I think it's usually a good thing to include both versions all the time to avoid regretting it later. Does that make sense?

I do see where you're coming from here, but is the gain really worth the additional pain of having 48 variations of the same lemma? Having 24 variations is bad enough already (particuarly since I only actually need 2 of them for the application I care about). Duplicating everything yet again by having `HasDerivAt` versions as well as `deriv` versions (and spinning out yet more little lemmas about order-connectedness), seems like a lot of very tedious effort – both for you and me right now, and for anyone who ends up having to maintain this in future.

(FWIW, the main reason I chose the `deriv` formulations over the `HasDerivAt` formulations is that it is easier to give them intuitive and systematic names! I don't find `le_slope_of_hasDerivWithinAt` very clear, it feels like it's putting the focus on the least interesting and specific object in the statement.)

PS. Actually, having looked at this again, maybe there is more gain than I realised: in fact, rearranging it this way allows one to get rid of the `uniqueDerivWithinAt` lemmas entirely, because `HasDeriv[Within]At.neg` doesn't need any uniqueness assumptions, unlike `deriv[Within]At.neg`. I will have a shot at reworking the code using this approach and see how it comes out.

Just to answer some of your remarks:

- regarding too many lemmas, usually Mathlib is not very conservative on that aspect, but I understand the hassle. I haven't used the calculus library extensively for some time, but in my experience if it's too annoying to duplicate everything it's actually better to just do the `Has` version, since you can just apply it to `hfd.hasDerivWithinAt`. In an ideal world we would have some automation to generate the `deriv` lemma from the `HasDeriv` version.

- regarding maintenance, of course it's an extra burden, but in that situation I don't think it would be that much more annoying (this is hard to objectively measure in advance of course).

- regarding the naming issue, I completely agree with you, and unfortunately I don't have any good answer to that. Often, I end up betting on "people will find the `deriv` version and notice the weirdly-named `HasDeriv` version just above", but this is not ideal.
I still think this (and the reverse version) could be its own lemma about `ordConnected` sets since you use it at least twice.

Happy to do so; but the natural place to put it is `Topology.Order.Basic`, which is already > 2000 lines long, so it will probably generate a linter error. Shall I do a quick PR splitting up that file, and then we can merge this afterwards?

I think you can just raise the indicated line limit in `style_exceptions.txt` if that is indeed a problem. If you want to split that file that would be great of course, but I don't think the intention behind these limits is to restrict putting lemmas in the proper places.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Analysis/Convex/Deriv): convex implies monotone deriv
